subject: Linux is repository slavery
name: Anonymous
text:
Almost all Linux users are slaves to repositories meanwhile Windows users can download an .exe file and get the latest version, bleeding edge beta version, or an ancient version of whatever software then want if they have the .exe .

We literally have made habit of frequently changing OS's just to get software we find effective. Solutions have been offered such as distro agnostic pack managers like flatpak and snap, and tools like appimage. However they are primarily ignored in favor of ancient tools like apt-get and .deb.

In Debian/Ubuntu's case apt-get should continue to exist for people who want it and how it saves a lot of space. But developers should be encouraged to take advantage of flatpak and appimage and even tar.gz bundles to prevent software from being chained to particular distros.

>>72507171
I'm not even talking about minimalism. I'm talking about the fact that you're just using a shit technology (snaps/flatpaks) and wasting time, disk size and bandwidth for VERY little benefit. Why the fuck would anyone pull 700MB of GNOME or KDE dependencies each time they want to use a 20MB software? You don't have to worry about "muh cross-distro support" if you're on debian or arch based distros. If you want the latest software releases then don't use a distro that uses ancient software.
>complain about PPAs, broken rolling OSes, or whatever.

>700MB of KDE/GNOME shit

The issue is binary proprietary software, that can't just be easily recompiled on any distro to begin with, and may not even work on a rolling distro because it's a case of software being too old.

I should say though that Flatpak does have a concept of dependency management. You won't need "700MB of GNOME or KDE dependencies" for every package because you only need to do it once, usually.

Go /p/ro:
• Please post images that are JPG format, smaller than 1 MB, and/or about 1000 pixels on the longest side.
• Expect to be judged harshly. Learn to deal with it.

Want:
• We come here for photos, so post yours as often as possible, even if "image unrelated" to your text.
• "Flickr/500px/Tumblr/Facebook/Portfolio" threads are for critique and networking
• Use "Recent Photos" threads if you are shy or only want to post a couple of photos.
• Shared raw files which we can collectively edit for discussion of post-processing techniques, are encouraged.
• Use the catalog to consolidate similar topics (photographic themes, images or technical gear threads)

Do Not Want:
• Go to >>>/r/ for specific Photoshop requests.
• Gear threads are discouraged, but identified as necessary. Many users simply hide these threads.

subject: /Nightwalk/ - Out after dark
name: Ari
text:
This thread is dedicated for pictures that were taken during blue hour, or at night. Feel free to share your photos and don't forget to criticise others.
----------------------------------------

Maybe share your stories or things you have experienced while lingering in the darkness, away from city lights, or directly below. I find peace and happiness in solitude and away from too many people. Of course I enjoy companionship, but walking alone, or with a friend at latenight is much more enjoyable than during the day.

I'm ready to get ripped apart for my white borders, but it's so much faster, than editing every single picture in my phone editor and resizing it to make it fit for /p/ posting.

I think you may need to review your developing technique. I develop both frequently and i've never had an issue. I'll quickly sum I'm what I do and maybe it will help.
>Dev in ddx
>Stop with water. Just rinsing for a few minutes
>Fix with ilford rapid fixer, just dump it undiluted into the tank and agitate constantly for a few minutes. Afterwards pur back into fixer bottle
>Rinse with water under constant agitation and after a few minutes add a tiny amount of dishsoap. Agitate and rinse until the bubbles are pretty much all gone.
>Hang from shower head. Maybe attach a binder clip to the bottom if it seems curly. Usually don't bother

If you need an adapter and it doesn't focus as well as it does on its *actual* native mount, it's not a native lens.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3526584
>wait so 43 mount right on? i only knew about 42
I think you're getting things a little confused.

There are three similarly named lens mounts:

* Micro Four Thirds (often abbreviated m4/3, m43, mft, or a few others). Modern electronic mirrorless lens mount for Micro Four Thirds system cameras.

* Four Thirds. Modern electronic SLR lens mount for Four Thirds system cameras. They have the same sensor size as micro Four Thirds, but they're SLRs, so they have a mirror box and associated longer flange-focal distance. You can mount Four Thirds lenses on a Micro Four Thirds camera with an adapter.

* m42. Old manual-focus lens system for film SLRs. This has been obsolete forever, but it was such a simple and once-ubiquitous system that a lot of camera makers used it, so there's a lot of old m42 lenses out there. Plus, they're easy to adapt on just about every modern camera system except for Nikon SLRs because Nikon had to be a fussy baby when they made the F mount. It's called m42 based on the size of the screw threads (or the diameter of the mount? Something like that). You can easily mount an m42 lens on a Micro Four Thirds camera with an adapter, but despite the fact that one's called m42 and the other is often called m43 and they're both, you know, lens mounts, they don't really have anything in common.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3527014

The focusing performance doesn't have anything to do with the mount when it comes to 43 and m43 though. The focusing discrepancy is purely because of many 43 lenses being designed to use PDAF, which only the EM1 has. On the EM1.2 and EM1x, focusing perfomance of most 43 lenses, especially the SHG lenses, is reportedly better than even on the E series bodies.

I'd say 43 lenses can definitely be considered native, at least on Olympus flagship bodies with PDAF. Even then, most 43 lenses focus just fine with CDAF only, and the performance hit isn't as extreme as you think. When you compare the focusing speed of 43 lenses on m43, they still outperform most native lenses on other mounts from the same era.

here are a few differences
>dota: supports are early game nightmares and can fuck up others with their strong abilities fitting a variety of needs
>league: supports are either aggro stun and kill or baby the carry

>dota: roaming heroes are much more of a common place and more of a nuisance since ones like spirit breaker or bounty hunter can appear at any time when you think of overextending to ruin your lane
>league: roamers are either typecast or need to do it through the necessity of their weakness as a champion see: aurelion sol for the former and alistar for the latter

>dota: jungle isn't nearly as a dominant position and the heroes that commonly jungle can't really make it in a lane against real bullies
>league: jungle is essentially a 2nd top laner or secondary hyper carry and is literally the single largest reason you win or lose games if riot decides they want jungle strong that patch

>dota: carries in dota are real ass carries and when they come online you either focus fire or they wipe you
>league: in recent times carries are less of a big deal with true hyper carries like yi, tryndamere and twitch falling out of favor for lesser ones such as kai'sa because she is more flexible in itemization
